title: Value investors' guide to the AFL grand final
text:
While Lloyd is a sports nut, he grew up in Brisbane playing rugby league and rugby union and didn’t know a whole lot about AFL when he became an inaugural member of the Captain’s Club coterie group in the Giant’s first season in 2012.

But Lloyd says he and his family have loved watching the club “grow and build on its strategy” – even if it was tough in the early years, when the young team was regularly thrashed.

“Now we’re not getting beaten by 100 points at half time it’s a lot better,” laughs Lloyd, who will join some 11,000 GWS members at the MCG on Saturday.

MLC chief executive Goeff Lloyd has watched the Giants build their culture. Peter Braig

“It’s a team that always plays in front of a crowd that’s barracking for someone else. The underdog, mongrel factor has actually helped drive that passion.”

To get the club off the ground the AFL handed GWS generous concessions in the league’s annual draft, allowing it to bring in the league’s hottest young talent. GWS then recruited experienced stars around this nucleus, such as its co-captain and talisman, Phil Davis.

But some of its most important players have been picked off football’s scrapheap.

Take Matt de Boer, arguably the Giant’s best player during the final series. The defensive midfielder – he’s known in AFL circles as a tagger, he is sent to quell the opposition’s best player – played in Fremantle’s 2013 grand final side, but three years later was delisted by the club. GWS gave him another chance.

Advertisement

Another example is ruckman Shane Mumford, who was lured out of retirement by the Giants this season for another tilt at premiership glory.

But defender Sam Reid is the most astounding story. He was delisted by the Giants twice – once in 2013 and again in 2017 – before re-joining the team last year via the rookie draft. He’s played every game this season and has emerged as a vital cog in the GWS defence.

GWS list manager Jason McCartney has developed a reputation as Buffett-type figure in AFL circles, having found similar unloved gems at the Western Bulldogs in their 2016 premiership.

McCartney tells Chanticleer that the AFL’s salary cap means every club is forced to tweak their list every year. And at a strong side, where the best players generally take up a bit more of the salary cap each, year through their strong performances, finding a few value investments is crucial.

“You’ve got to be able to find some role playing, cheaper options,” he says.

Major League’s Baseball’s Moneyball movement – which is based on using data and analytics to find cheaper but highly effective players – has spread throughout world sports, including the AFL.

McCartney employs a consultant who helps assess the Giant’s current playing list and potential recruits. But while he says the league’s clubs are only starting to test the limits of how analytics can be used, good old fashioned gut instinct still has its place.

“Does the data process throw up something occasional that is a bit of gold? Yes. But I think the validation is just as important.”

Advertisement

Richmond will have its own value investment gem running out on Saturday: shock late inclusion Marlion Pickett, who was picked up the Tigers in this year’s mid season draft. He will play his first ever game at AFL level on Saturday.

But analytics expert Ben Darwin, the co-founder of GAIN LINE Analytics and former Wallaby, says the Tigers’ recent success – the club won its first premiership in more than three decades in 2017 – is down to another value investing strategy: buy and hold.

“Richmond’s success has actually come through a lack of recruiting,” he says. “The teams that trade the most tend to do the worst.”

Darwin’s firm measures around 1000 pieces of data around AFL sides, but his focus in less on individual performance and more on the cohesion of the team.

Clubs that have stability in terms of their playing list, coaching staff and broad game style, tend to develop a level of coherence that is particularly in crucial in AFL.

Unlike baseball, where players specialise in particular role have limited interaction with each other, AFL players can play in different roles, and rely much more on the performance of their team mates.

Darwin’s analysis shows in the AFL, player movements between clubs are around 30 per cent lower than in the NRL, and less than half of that they are in the English Premier League.

“In order to win in the AFL, it actually requires far more patience than any other league in the world,” he says, adding that the speed with which the Giants have made their first grand final is impressive.

It’s all set up for a fascinating game. Richmond look deserved of favouritism, but after talking to Darwin, Chanticleer can’t shake a feeling that picking a first-gamer for the grand final could threaten their coherence.

And as every investor knows, momentum is important. Perhaps a Giant upset is looming.
description: GWS Giants versus the Richmond Tigers is a battle between two value investing strategies: finding unloved gems, and buy-and-hold.
